#Text=KNIGHT-ERRANTRY AS A TRADE
#Text=Sandy and I were on the road again , next morning , bright and early .

#Text=It was so good to open up one 's lungs and take in whole luscious barrels-ful of the blessed God 's untainted , dew-fashioned , woodland-scented air once more , after suffocating body and mind for two days and nights in the moral and physical stenches of that intolerable old buzzard-roost !
#Text=I mean , for me : of course the place was all right and agreeable enough for Sandy , for she had been used to high life all her days .
#Text=Poor girl , her jaws had had a wearisome rest now for a while , and I was expecting to get the consequences .

#Text=I was right ; but she had stood by me most helpfully in the castle , and had mightily supported and reinforced me with gigantic foolishnesses which were worth more for the occasion than wisdoms double their size ; so I thought she had earned a right to work her mill for a while , if she wanted to , and I felt not a pang when she started it up :
#Text=“ Now turn we unto Sir Marhaus that rode with the damsel of thirty winter of age southward -- ”
#Text=“ Are you going to see if you can work up another half-stretch on the trail of the cowboys , Sandy ? ”
#Text=“ Even so , fair my lord . ”
#Text=“ Go ahead , then .
#Text=I wo n't interrupt this time , if I can help it .
#Text=Begin over again ; start fair , and shake out all your reefs , and I will load my pipe and give good attention . ”
#Text=“ Now turn we unto Sir Marhaus that rode with the damsel of thirty winter of age southward .

#Text=And so they came into a deep forest , and by fortune they were nighted , and rode along in a deep way , and at the last they came into a courtelage where abode the duke of South Marches , and there they asked harbour .
#Text=And on the morn the duke sent unto Sir Marhaus , and bad him make him ready .
#Text=And so Sir Marhaus arose and armed him , and there was a mass sung afore him , and he brake his fast , and so mounted on horseback in the court of the castle , there they should do the battle .

#Text=So there was the duke already on horseback , clean armed , and his six sons by him , and every each had a spear in his hand , and so they encountered , whereas the duke and his two sons brake their spears upon him , but Sir Marhaus held up his spear and touched none of them .
#Text=Then came the four sons by couples , and two of them brake their spears , and so did the other two .
#Text=And all this while Sir Marhaus touched them not .
#Text=Then Sir Marhaus ran to the duke , and smote him with his spear that horse and man fell to the earth .
#Text=And so he served his sons .
#Text=And then Sir Marhaus alight down , and bad the duke yield him or else he would slay him .
#Text=And then some of his sons recovered , and would have set upon Sir Marhaus .
#Text=Then Sir Marhaus said to the duke , Cease thy sons , or else I will do the uttermost to you all .
#Text=When the duke saw he might not escape the death , he cried to his sons , and charged them to yield them to Sir Marhaus .
#Text=And they kneeled all down and put the pommels of their swords to the knight , and so he received them .

#Text=And then they holp up their father , and so by their common assent promised unto Sir Marhaus never to be foes unto King Arthur , and thereupon at Whitsuntide after , to come he and his sons , and put them in the king 's grace . *
#Text=[ *Footnote : The story is borrowed , language and all , from theMorte d'Arthur. -- M.T. ]
#Text=“ Even so standeth the history , fair Sir Boss .
#Text=Now ye shall wit that that very duke and his six sons are they whom but few days past you also did overcome and send to Arthur 's court ! ”
#Text=“ Why , Sandy , you ca n't mean it ! ”
#Text=“ An I speak not sooth , let it be the worse for me . ”
#Text=“ Well , well , well , -- now who would ever have thought it ?
#Text=One whole duke and six dukelets ; why , Sandy , it was an elegant haul .
#Text=Knight-errantry is a most chuckle-headed trade , and it is tedious hard work , too , but I begin to see that there is money in it , after all , if you have luck .
#Text=Not that I would ever engage in it as a business , for I would n't .
#Text=No sound and legitimate business can be established on a basis of speculation .
#Text=A successful whirl in the knight-errantry line --
#Text=now what is it when you blow away the nonsense and come down to the cold facts ?
#Text=It 's just a corner in pork , that 's all , and you ca n't make anything else out of it .
#Text=You 're rich --
#Text=yes , -- suddenly rich -- for about a day , maybe a week ; then somebody corners the market on you , and down goes your bucket-shop ;
#Text=ai n't that so , Sandy ? ”
#Text=“ Whethersoever it be that my mind miscarrieth , bewraying simple language in such sort that the words do seem to come endlong and overthwart -- ”
#Text=“ There 's no use in beating about the bush and trying to get around it that way , Sandy , it 's so , just as I say .
#Text=I know it 's so .

#Text=And , moreover , when you come right down to the bedrock , knight-errantry is worse than pork ; for whatever happens , the pork 's left , and so somebody 's benefited anyway ; but when the market breaks , in a knight-errantry whirl , and every knight in the pool passes in his checks , what have you got for assets ?
#Text=Just a rubbish-pile of battered corpses and a barrel or two of busted hardware .
#Text=Can you call those assets ?
#Text=Give me pork , every time .
#Text=Am I right ? ”
